argument and I don't know it and I'd like to hear it. Um, which there has to be a God in order for
that to matter, but that's a conversation. But when it comes to the emotional part of this,
it's all about grieving. This is where I am and this is where I live. And this is,
this is a consequence of what I believe. And that's so much of what this podcast is meant to be about
is how do I rebuild with that? And, and the, the part of it is there is a trust factor in,
um, actually I preached about it Sunday that God has my best in mind, that he is,
he is creating his best for me and for his creation, even in allowing these horrible things.
I'm, I'm okay with not understanding that and I've, it's not like I haven't faced it.
Yeah. Um, and I think it can be faced and I think it can be accepted. And I think,
I think God is big enough to handle when we're ticked off. I think that's one is a lot of people
need to go toe to toe with God in that moment and tell him what they're thinking and express to him
what's going on with them in a weird way. I even tell people, sometimes you need to learn,
you have to actually write a forgiveness letter to God, God, I forgive you for hurting me like this.
And that feels weird as if who am I to forgive God, but I mean, relationally speaking, of course,
it's appropriate for us to forgive God. It's, it's like a nurse who sets a bone who says,
I'm so sorry, this is going to really hurt. Yeah. And, and it's appropriate for you to say,
I forgive you for really hurting me. In that case, I can maybe, if I'm aware,
medically, I can know them setting the bone is maybe saving a limb, but it still hurts.
And I still can forgive them for hurting me. Um, and so I've had plenty of people work through
how angry are you at God? What does that anger about? How did he hurt you? What is his role in
that? And then can you forgive him for hurting you like that? So hopefully that's appropriate.
I feel like David goes through that cycle several times. That's what I was going to say. It's almost
shocking sometimes if you're not used to communicating to God that way. And then you read some of these
Psalms where it's like, where are you? How long? All day long I've tried and you're, and then I
like, I think it's Psalm 70 where he even wrestles with, I almost slipped into this wrong way of
thinking that I look at all of the Godless people and they just have it all. They can do whatever
they want. They've got all the food they want. There's no accountability, the other stuff.
And then he realizes, okay, but that was wrong. I see their end result, but it's so easy to look
at your immediate circumstances. And what he says in there, actually, he says in vain, all in vain
have I kept my heart pure. Like he's wrestling with, have I even been good for no reason?
What's the point? All those people living however they want really look happy. And here I am trying
to live for the Lord and it's just really bad. But I think, so I was going to mention that about how
the Psalms are so often like that, that they're very real about their emotions and they usually
land back on, but this is what I know. But it doesn't mean they're not suffering, but you've got
the whole book of Job related to that. You've got so many Psalms. And then we talked about this
before, but that's essentially what the cross was all about, that it was God dealing with the problem
of evil. And in one sense you could go, well, if you want to talk about innocent suffering,
Jesus knows a little bit about, he's the most innocent person in the world who suffered the
greatest, the wrath of God. But I like also to not think that even though God allows this,
it doesn't mean that so many times physical therapists as they're working you through
something will be like, I'm sorry, I'm sorry. I remember, I think it was our eye doctor that
my wife was having something done and he kept going, I'm sorry. But he did it anyways. So he's
saying, I'm sorry while he did it. So they're not in competition with each other. Like, well,
if you were sorry, you wouldn't, it was like, sorry, this hurts you, but I'm going to do it anyways,
because I love you. But in 2 Corinthians 1, I like how many times it mentions the word comfort.
It says, blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies and God of
all comfort who comforts us in our affliction so that we may be able to comfort those who are in
any affliction with the comfort with which we ourselves are comforted by God. And then he talks
about sufferings and even goes on and says, we had been through so much affliction. He says in
verse eight, it was, the burden was beyond our strength and we despaired of life itself. And so
many times I read into it's like, Oh, but you're Paul, you have great faith. But it's Paul going,
no, I thought my life is over. Like I really had despaired. And then he says, indeed, we had felt
that we had received the sentence of death, but that was to make us rely not on ourselves,
but on God who raises the dead. And he says he delivered us. So it doesn't take away that
here's exactly what I suffered or here's what I learned out of it. But ultimately he knows,
I know what it did for sure is it made me not rely on myself and what I could see and what I
could do. Because I was beyond my strength. It was beyond what I thought I could bear,
but there was a motive there was to move me towards deeper faith in this God of all comfort.
But again, it doesn't mean you're not hurting. And that's one of the buckets. I mean, one of
the buckets is I need to learn something. I need to grow up. And sometimes pain is what causes us
to grow up. How many times do people leave a job they should have left a long time ago because of
discomfort? And finally it's like, okay, I just can't stand it anymore. Well, you should have left
10 years ago, but you didn't because it was comfortable and until it became uncomfortable or
we always joke about, you know, I struggled with weight issues. And so, you know, my vision
starts being weird. And I asked the doctor about it and he goes, Oh, that's, you know,
pre diabetes setting in. So you're, you're the sugar in your liquids in your eyes is
throwing off your vision. I was like, okay, that's terrifying. Like what, I don't know what that
means. But I, and so I'm like, he said, well, you just got to lose some weight and get in better
shape. And, but I still like, by the way, I still had a hard time motivating myself. I have to put
money on the line, apparently to motivate me. Round is a shape. Exactly. Circle hater.
It's Psalm 73 is the one you're right. Oh, 73. Chris. And by the way, that sounds like twice now.
I've, I've like, Oh, it's this chapter. I looked it up. It's not like I need to throw it out there.
The difference is you, you knew it was there somewhere. And then so we're, we're a good tag
team. You, you know what though, you know where it says somewhere and then I'll Google it.
That's great. Okay. Wait. So you, you mentioned, unless you want to talk
through something else, you mentioned the problem of evil. And so I just wanted to
just kind of get an overview when you say the problem of evil, because that'll probably keep
coming up. And if we, you know, we're hoping to talk with other people who bring this up,
when you say the problem of evil, what do you mean or what do other people mean? I guess
Mm-hmm. What we lined up before was the idea that an all-powerful God could stop evil or innocent
suffering. And then gotcha. Okay. That's what you're saying is that an all-loving God would,
which is that's the one that we were suspect. Right. Okay. Not necessarily true there, but,
but there's suffering and evil. Therefore there's not an all-loving, all-powerful God.
But what we said before was the third leg of the stool was that God is all knowing.
And that's what we're dealing with right now. That's right. Okay. So that's why that second
argument falls apart when you say an all-loving God wouldn't allow suffering. Right. And, and it's
at the general level, again, philosophically at the general level, that's just a false premise.
You cannot prove an all-loving God would not allow suffering because there's plenty of examples of
a loving person causing suffering. Right. Okay. And then that's what you're talking about,
the dentist and all that. Yes. Exactly. Now, that being said, that's the philosophical argument.
When my friends come and say, you know, we waited 10 years, we got pregnant, and then the baby died,
me going, well, you can't, you can't prove philosophically God doesn't have a good,
morally positive reason, is not offering any company that doesn't help. And so they probably
already know that unless they want to talk about that. That's not, like, that's not, that's not the
answer to the emotional problem of suffering and evil. It's that's a, and by the way, I am in no way
minimizing that emotions are a powerful part of who we are. They're not a minimal part of who we are.
And so, and so to say, how do we engage emotionally? Well, there's things we know to do
to motivate ourselves to grieve well. And one of my missed, mentioned a second ago was the honesty
with God being honest with God. We don't ever have to back off on that. And again, if you,
if you wondered it, read the Psalms, the man after God's own heart. I mean, he blasts
God several times. I mean, all through the Psalms, like, and it is, it's rough language. It's rough
talk from a shepherd king. And he's, he has spent plenty of time alone and he's watched his world
fall apart. And sometimes it falls apart because he's an idiot. And sometimes it falls apart,
even when he's being totally appropriate. And sometimes it weirdly falls apart when David
seems to think he's doing the right thing. And God's like, Nope, that was the wrong thing. Now
that you're going to mean it's the buckets of is God, is God giving me a consequence directly
from him? That is a possible bucket. Is it God's giving me consequences? God's allowing me to face
consequences of somebody else's sin. Yeah. I mean, every child of divorce knows what that's like.
And so you pick pick every, any one of those buckets and, and for some people it's valuable
to go, okay, what's your part? What's somebody else's part? What's God's part? What can you learn
from this? Can be valuable, but part of it just helping people recognize God, God's not afraid of
your honesty. And, and you're not going to somehow burn bridges with him that can't be recovered.
There is no such thing with him. And even having a really good reason still doesn't change the fact
that it's happening. It doesn't help setting the fact that someone's, our good friend of ours just
went through, Kevin East just went through a year of chemo. Yeah. I mean, it chemo is, is like,
Hey, we're going to almost kill you. We're going to put you through toward what would be torture
under any other for a year. And by the way, come schedule and come back in another four weeks for
us to do it again for six or eight sessions. And then, and it may help you. It may not,
it may help you. It may not. And so it's, it again, to say, yeah, there's a good reason for this. And
it's a nightmare to live through it. And then, so that's one. And then another one that's very
important is our natural tendency is also to isolate when we're in pain. And I don't, I don't
know where that comes from. I don't know what it is about us that the tendency is to isolate. I
don't know if that's a, I know this will be a point of conversation. That's a, an evolved trait,
or if it's a psychological trait, but it is that, that tendency to say, you know, like a dog that
gets hurt, wants to go crawl in the corner and lick its wounds. Cause it, I don't, I don't know
what all the motivation, but there's something in us that a lot of people want to do. That is,
I'm going to cut ties. I'm going to back off. I'm going to isolate myself. But the problem is that's
not healthy. It's not healthy for the dog or the human that what we actually need is care and
comfort and protection and provision and people to wrap around us. But it is fascinating to watch
us sometimes chase the very people off who are trying to love us, how hard that can be.
So being honest with God, sometimes being honest with ourselves, anger and the anger and forgiveness
that we need to give ourselves is a huge one. And then the anger and forgiveness of other people
letting us down. Cause humans are frail and flawed, and you will learn about that when you suffer.
And, and the, the ways that you wish people would help you and comfort you and push past your
barriers and, and all that kind of stuff. And they don't, man, that can really, that can carry a lot
of pain too. And so usually there's a whole series of, I need to be honest and open about the anger
that I'm dealing with and the hurt I'm dealing with and the pain I'm dealing with. And then
people are going to say and do dumb things in the midst of our grief. Y'all appreciate. I actually
have done counseling with people who had like the death of a parent when they were a child.
And they are much more traumatized by what people said and did after the death of the parent than
the death of the parent. So that's a whole other conversation. Like, you know, I want to go off on,
but I'm not going to, but that is very often, especially well-meaning Christians just need to
close their mouth sometime. And well, I was going to say too, the way we always do put down Job's
friends because their conclusion was wrong, but their initial approach, if you read in Job 2,
which I'm confident now that it's Job 2, when they show up to comfort, it says,
they made an appointment together to come to show him sympathy and comfort him. When they saw him
from a distance, they did not recognize him and they, they raised their voices and wept and they
tore their robes and sprinkled dust on their heads towards heaven. And then they sat with him on the
ground seven days and seven nights and no one spoke a word to him for they saw that his suffering
was very great. So their mistake was when they did open their mouth, their conclusion. But those are
really great reminders of what to do with it. When someone is grieving, you don't always have
to have an answer. I think we want to jump to, this is the reason, right? Or just let God off the hook.
But I like what you said, Chris, about having to forgive others. And I remember you preaching on
this, I don't know, maybe in the last year, but you define forgiveness as like having to cancel a
debt. Like, that's the, yep. Where you unpack that because that's a great, I think the way you phrase
it was so freeing in my mind. Like that's a great way to think about it. So again, this is a whole
conversation that we won't go down, but the, there is an article on the, on my personal web page about
this and on Aletheia's web page about it. But I tell people when I, I think when I look at the
Bible for the concept of forgiveness, it is always inextricably linked to debt. And in fact, when you
learned the, you know, I learned the Lord's Prayer as a kid in a Episcopal school and it has all the
cool S's, forgive us our trespasses as we forgive those who trespass against us. I need the S filter
on that for that. Yeah, yeah, yeah. Similants. Which I loved as a kid, but I didn't know what
I'm trespassed as it meant. Like I walk, I didn't own any property, but I walked on everybody's
property. So it was like a good deal for me. Hey, forgive me for walking on your property and I'll
forgive you for walking all night. Anyway, but most modern translations have forgive us our debts
because that's the, that's a good translation. And so what, what a debt is, is anything occur,
incurred against us mentally, psychologically, emotionally, and of course, financially, whatever.
And so to forgive a debt is really nothing more than to say, I expect and require no payment on
what you owe me. And so if I owned Colson, $1,000 and he forgave me that debt, he would just be
saying, I expect and require no payment. Now that doesn't take away my moral obligation. If I decide
to pay and as of, which is appropriate, if I decide it's the right thing to do, whatever, all
that's good. But, but that's all it means to, it doesn't mean he has to loan me another $1,000.
It doesn't mean that I, you know, he's like, well, now I've got to let him babysit my children.
Yeah, we got to be best friends now.
We got to be best buds. Like, no, there's still healthy boundaries to be put in place. And
I mean, I, you can forgive a family member who's an abuser and, and which would be a lot,
because they've stolen a lot from you. And, and that's actually usually what I have people do is
create a letter of debt. Right. Here's what you took from me. Here's what you stole from me.
And that's intense. That's some intense work. And you get this thing done, big and small. And in the
end, you essentially say, okay, so we unpack it, we spend hours doing it. And then you say, okay,
we got to the end. And okay, so they owe you, there's a ledger and there's this number that is
an unpayable debt. Knowing how could anyone ever pay you back for being abusive, for example,
like it's just not payable. So as a young lady, she was 12, forgiving her father for abandoning
the family. She heard last sentence was she actually taught me a word, I had to go look it up.
She said, you couldn't pay me back. If you tried and spent the rest of your life, you should try.
But that's no longer my problem. I forgive your debt. And I absolve what you owe me. So I had to
go look that up. 12 year old girl taught me a word absolve means to blot out. And so essentially,
that's the exact language she got to the end of the ledger. There's a number there. If he spent
the rest of his life trying to pay it, he would fail, which is what he should do. But that's between
him and God, not between him and her anymore. Because she expects and requires no payment. And
she has like just taking liquid paper and that final number, she's blotting it out. That doesn't
mean she trusts him. It doesn't mean they go their buddies. It doesn't mean it didn't happen.
It doesn't mean it didn't happen. It doesn't mean it didn't hurt. It doesn't mean it wasn't
horrifically painful. And it doesn't mean that he won't continue to incur new debt against her.
It doesn't mean that it makes all the consequences of his sin go away. Like none of those are what
Jesus, I think, has talked about when he talks about forgiveness. That's why it's so closely
linked to debt. It is it is it is it just an ex statement, a new covenantial agreement,
I expect and require no payment on the debt you owe me. And there's also for Christians,
especially the whole model of purchasing plays into that. Like I've been bought with a price.
So if you owe if I if you know if you owe my company money, and somebody buys my company,
you don't make a check to me anymore. You try to make a check to them now. And so what happens is
when we are purchased lock stock and barrel by God, now any debts owed us are really actually
owed him. They're now between that person and him. And, and it's no longer my job to require payment.
And what's weird is how often we actually make ourselves pay for their debt.
Whole other conversation. But I think very often when people face these moments, these crises
of suffering, especially that causes them to start deconstructing one, they may need to deconstruct,
like we've said over and over again, because they may have been trusting God for something
he never promised that he's as C.S. Lewis said, I'm afraid there may be things about this God
I no longer like, which is not required. I don't have to like everything about right.
And then, but then part of it is I may, I may be in a position to forgive him.
And to accept his forgiveness in the midst of that. And that's, those are tough. That's tough
for anybody, the psychological challenges of pushing through that kind of stuff. And very often,
I think for people, it and I don't, this is not meant to imply laziness, it's meant to imply
difficulty that they say, it's just it's just easier. It's an easier path to just walk away.
Then to reconstruct something new, or to reconstruct something out of the rubble.
But I like what you said yesterday that you would never go watch any of those remodeling shows
of the ended with the demolishing demo phase, move that bus and there's just
knock down rubble. Great episode. It's the exciting part is watching them what they do.
Yes.
After that. And so that's why deconstructing is always, okay, step one, but then what are you
going to build those? I feel like those shows, if though if Jesus was alive now,
he would use those shows as parables. Like, you know, the kingdom of heaven is like,
you know, Rick and Joanna and he would wait, chip chip and Joanna. Sorry, sorry, chip,
sorry, chip. If you're listening, you're listening. I'm the, but actually caught a few seconds of
other episodes the other day. And they're talking in a hallway and he's like, it's all going to come
down. She's going, what? And he's like, yeah, none of this. Like, I thought this was a good deal.
I thought we did it. The smart, the whole thing has to come down and we have to start from
scratch. She's like, we're going to lose so much money. He goes, our new goal,
lose less money than we think. But that's, that is what it feels like. It feels like to deconstruct
can feel exactly, you're looking around going, none of really none of this. I've got to start
all over. And so sometimes it just feels easier. Just like, forget. Yeah. Yeah. Tough. And it can
be scary, but again, for a lot of people, it's, this is your faith becoming your faith.
Because you had all these unquestioned answers and that never really was your
own. It can be scary. And so it might be easier just to say, well, then I don't believe any of it.
This, this is part of why I went into therapy guys. This is, this actually is, is because I
felt like we have so much good theology and so much good Bible teaching and so much good
of things. And I think what stymies people sometimes isn't the theological issues. It's
the psychological ones. It's a state of our heart. And those are in no way in contradiction
with each other. So I defy anybody who teaches that concept that. But having, but being in the,
in the world of addressing those things as a profession. Yeah. That makes a lot of sense.
Learning how to do that because what I saw people even 30, 40 years ago, moving away from
like the struggles they seem to have with God very often weren't really all that theological.
Sometimes they are, and I'm not minimizing that. And sometimes theology helps us heal and rebuild.
And it certainly gives us material to rebuild with good biblical theology built, gives us material
that can last through the next storm that we hit. I know we'll come back to this time and time again,
because of how commonly the connected this is, but I'm looking forward to us moving into,
because I think something may be valuable to people is to hear from us what holds us together
in the storm. So why, why didn't I walk away? And by the way, my friend is still a pastor, I think.
Last time I checked and he got back on speaking terms with God at some point.
I'm looking forward to getting to where we're talking about. Here's what holds us through the storm.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
It'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear
discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South
Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
